summary: This document is an email chain from July 13, 2020, discussing the upcoming bail hearing for Ghislaine Maxwell. A journalist from News Corporation requests information about the hearing, and internal responses from prosecutors indicate they will not share arguments or victim identities with the press in advance.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the email chain and the upcoming bail hearing in the criminal case USA v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Megan Patin
persons.context: Appears as a sender in the email chain, likely a member of the prosecution team handling the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Me an Palin
persons.context: A journalist for News Corporation (The Sun, NY Post, Wall Street Journal) covering the Maxwell case, who emails the prosecution team with questions about the upcoming bail hearing.

connections.description: Patin is a prosecutor involved in the criminal case against Maxwell, representing the government.
Palin is a journalist covering the legal proceedings against Maxwell.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Bail Hearing
events.description: Upcoming bail hearing for Ghislaine Maxwell, discussed in emails from July 13, 2020. The hearing will be conducted remotely with an in-person overflow room, and victims will participate via call-in.

keyFacts: The bail hearing for Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled for July 14, 2020, and was to be conducted with remote participation.
Victims were to be heard at the bail hearing, either directly, through their attorney, or through the prosecution, but would not testify in the traditional sense.
A journalist from News Corporation requested advance details about prosecution arguments and victim identities, which prosecutors internally mocked as an unrealistic expectation.
The email chain reveals the prosecution's stance on not disclosing strategic arguments or victim information to the press before court proceedings.
